info.headline: Flood Warning issued November 11 at 5:42PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 530 AM EST SATURDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of western North Carolina, including the following counties, Burke and Caldwell. * WHEN...Until 530 AM EST Saturday. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams is ongoing, including farmland, nurseries, campgrounds, boat-access areas, low-water crossings, and low-lying secondary roadways. Inundation up to several feet deep is possible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 527 PM EST, Heavy rainfall has ended and only light rainfall is expected through the remainder of tonight. However, storm-total rainfall of 4-7" in the headwaters of the Johns River watershed, including along Wilson Creek and Mulberry Creek, has caused significant rises and Minor flooding from Collettsville to Adako to Chesterfield. The Johns River at Corpening Bridge Rd is currently at 14.01 feet and continues a steady rise. Minor Flood Stage is 12 feet. The Johns River is expected to continue to rise over the next 2-4 hours, and should crest between 15-16 feet later tonight. At these levels, extensive flooding within the Johns River valley below Collettsville is ongoing, impacting farmland, nurseries, outbuildings, boat-access areas, low- water crossings and adjacent roads. Inundation of 2-4` is likely in some locations adjacent to the river. Floodwaters are likely impacting Corpening Bridge Rd, Playmore Beach Rd, Old Johns River Rd, Johns River Rd, and Johns River Loop. It will take several more hours for the Johns River to fall back below Minor Flood Stage and may not fall below Action/Advisory (bankfull) Stage until later Saturday morning. This Flood Warning will therefore remain in effect through the overnight hours. - Some locations that may experience flooding include... Adako, Chesterfield, and Collettsville. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Turn around, don`t drown.
